comments.body:
That's.... An impossible request. For a few reasons,

First, I'll assume for a second you're getting this idea similar to what terraria did with their official tmodloader. While that would be an interesting idea to have a launcher dedicated to mods, Everything else you wrote is impossible;

1. Making additions or games without knowing how to code (you need to know how to design for mods as well) is already hard and not worth it.
2. Running fabric mods and forge mods is not much of an issue (the mods aren't locked to the launcher) but I don't see how that's important. However, You can't run mods from different versions. Lets say 1.8 and 1.12 as an example, Since combat changed drastically then different mods may work differently and since mods were specifically tailored and created to that specific version, There's no telling what would happen in other HIGHER versions of the game.
3. Changing the mods while playing without restarting is also impossible. You It's like saying to take an apple from a tree you didn't plant, When you set certain mods and make a new world for example some mods load certain biomes and mechanics to the game while you open it. It's impossible to "change mods" while being "loaded in" since the entire point of loading into the game is loading in the content. Texture packs can be changed since they're a minor part of the game but you can't add code into an existing world and expect it to work.

*Thanks for reading,
-Beelzeboul
Make modding easier

I think it's a great idea. There are a lot of mods that is uncompatible due by the fact that it is really difficult to touch to the minecraft code. it makes that we can't enjoy old mods on newer version of the game, because they were coded to fit with an old code. I'm not a specialist of the question, but yeah. Please Mojang add this feature.

While mods are impossible on different Minecraft versions and mods also load without restarting the game, the only reason you should have an official mod loader is to have to commit to Forge, Neoforge, Fabric or Quilt. After all, you can already change the game a lot with data packs. Maybe you could give them more functionality, like data driven items, events and fluids.

It would be best if 360 maps uploaded to the cloud would appear there, just like the ones from the One Edition.
But even the "upload to Xbox One" option does not work with Bedrock.

It only seems to work if first uploaded to Xbox One Edition.
But Xbox One Edition is no longer available and prices for used disk versions are quite high.

Yeah, I want to be able to transfer and back up all my Xbox 360 Minecraft worlds to the Xbox One Minecraft or Minecraft Bedrock without all the hassle tbh, also able to transfer 360 worlds not just on Xbox One Minecraft copy but other copies of the game on other platforms like PS4, PS5, the Switch and such, also the same with the PS3, WiiU and 3DS copies of the game and worlds on them too, I've bought an Xbox One S just for this and have to find the Xbox One Edition (physical disc version) of the game in stores because it's only Bedrock on the Marketplace, also transfer and port worlds onto other platforms for the game like if you have an Xbox 360, Series X and/or Xbox One but you have a PS3, PS4, PS5 and/or The Switch and want to play with world or transfer/port it to such, there's should be an option to do so tbh

See the problem is, Consoles aren't computers. They can't run JavaScript because they aren't made to do so. Because Java edition is coded in Java it cannot be put on any platform other than a PC.

I signed in just to dispell a falsehood someone said, first of all, consoles technically are PCs starting in the PS3/360 era, though your not wrong to assume java is not *pre*installed, though there is actually nothing at all stoping them from selling a game with java binarys packaged with it, the original Xbox 360 version and first Xbox One versions of MC were and are still java, so it CAN be done, they just don't want too, thanks for your time :)

Hi

This post by Aubrey Norris, though she's not a Dev, is exactly what I'm talking about. Builds a wheat "wash" farm, from the sounds of it. It does not work as intended because Bedrock's trap-door mechanics do not work like Java mechanics. FOR NO GOOD REASON, this is "not a bug, it's a Platform Specific Feature (PSF)!"

Quote: Eating your own dog food, also called dogfooding, is a slang term used to reference a scenario in which a company uses its own product to test and promote the product. /Quote

How much of this PSF business would vanish if Devs had to periodically swap and play the Minecraft platform they were not working on? Ignoring the "deep, technical Redstone" stuff, just simple, basic game mechanics.

https://twitter.com/CornerHardMC/status/1166489238700838912?s=20

"We play both versions in both Redmond and Stockholm! Parity issues are frustrating, but we're working hard on getting them squared away"

This is great news! The gameplay experience between both should really be in sync, and it sounds as if my request is in practice.
I would except you can't post photos in the feedback site.

I kind of agree with 418219364752 ...

Minecraft shouldn't need to include political messages or anything. Although... you could be a little nicer about it, dude.

The other comments are wrong about this (as of now it is hate) because:

1. People liking others in different ways is not political. It is a fact not an opinion.

2. Being straight has always been accepted and never denied. People are not disowned or killed because they are cis or straight. Also anyone who has ever demanded that there be straight pride events or flags are very homophobic and want to act like the victim.
Yes please, also we're close to the pride month!

Message to Mojang / Minecraft
In 2023, you added a Pride cape to Minecraft ‚Äî a symbol of inclusion and support for the LGBTQ+ community. Now, in June 2025, that cape is gone. It‚Äôs disappointing to see such a meaningful gesture taken away.

Visibility and respect should never be temporary. We hope Mojang will choose once again to stand clearly in support of all communities.
